title: How to Make a Memorial Scrapbook

steps.headline: Buy a classic scrapbook.
steps.description: You may want to choose a scrapbook in the person's favorite color, or in a classic white. Buy scrapbook pages in a neutral color, such as cream. Scrapbooks commonly come in 6 by 6, 8 by 8, 8.5 by 11 and 12 by 12 sizes. If you are planning a comprehensive book that includes more than pictures, you should choose either 8.5 by 11 or 12 by 12. You can buy a pack of pages that can be inserted into the scrapbook as needed.

steps.headline: Search for photos of the person.
steps.description: Ask for contributions from friends and family. Since families often set out pictures during funerals and wakes, you may be able to take these photos and scan them in before or after the service. It is a good idea to scan all photos that you plan to use into the computer. If you don't have a scanner or computer that can do this, you can ask a friend or get an archival service to do it. Keep the photos on a computer disk and print them anew with a digital printer or at a local photo lab. Then, give the photos back to friends or family so that they can keep them as a part of their photo albums.

steps.headline: Ask people who were close to the person to journal about their experience.
steps.description: Ask for 100 to 300 words from each person in the form of a letter, note or memory. Give people at least a month to think about this and write from their heart.

steps.headline: You can include this in your scrapbook in 1 of 2 ways.
steps.description: You can either recopy each person's prose onto your scrapbook pages with a decorative scrapbooking pen. You can also frame each person's note like it is a photo.

steps.headline: Collect memorabilia from the person's life and/or the funeral.
steps.description: For example, try to find a wedding announcement, wedding invitation, retirement party invitation, newspaper article that they were featured in, obituary and funeral program.

steps.headline: Research the person's favorite music.
steps.description: Type up or journal lyrics from their favorite songs.

steps.headline: Research the person's favorite books and authors.
steps.description: Include quotes from these authors throughout the book.

steps.headline: Buy decorative paper, tags and stickers from your local scrapbook store.
steps.description: Many stores sell sets of thematic scrapbooking accents, including themes such as mother, father, vacation, wedding and more. These can help to make a scrapbook look professional very quickly.

steps.headline: Gather condolence cards that were given at the funeral.
steps.description: If there were too many to include, make a list of people who gave cards and flowers to be included on a page.

steps.headline: Mat your photos with cardstock.
steps.description: Measure your photo and then add ⁄4 to 2 inches (0.6 to 5.1 cm) to the measurements for the cardstock, depending upon how large you want your frame to be. Affix the photo to the cardstock with acid-free glue. You can employ many different matting techniques with both photos and notes. You can do a double or triple mat where the mats are in larger sizes and different colors. You can also alternate cardstock with decorative paper or use white gel pens to draw borders onto the photo mat.

steps.headline: Create a title page featuring a large picture of the person or pet and their name in large titles.
steps.description: You may want to also include the dates of their life.

steps.headline: Choose your page titles, for your subsequent pages.
steps.description: Most scrapbooks are divided by themes and titles. The title showcases each theme. You may want to consider titles like Our Father, Working Mom, Growing Up, In Remembrance, Golden Memories, Missing You, Travels Together, and any other 1 to 5 word phrases that describe a time of life or a feeling surrounding that person. You will need to choose how you want to place your titles at the top of each page or group of pages. Options include writing the titles freehand, typing them out on the computer, using stencils or using alphabet stickers.

steps.headline: Convey the person's life in the first half of the book.
steps.description: Most memorial books include information and photos of the person's life along with their passing. Use the first half of the book in themed pages about their childhood, education, work life, passions, hobbies, children, husband and/or retirement. Include memories that people have written during this first half of the book. If there is an especially good or funny memory, use that as the page's focal point. Find photos and memorabilia that accent this memory.

steps.headline: Convey the person's memory in the last half of the book.
steps.description: In this portion, include the journaling that you asked people to do, cards, the obituary and funeral program.

steps.headline: Include a family tree in 1 of your pages.
steps.description: After you have gathered information about the person's family, outline the genealogy in an artful way over 2 pages.

steps.headline: Layer each page with matted photos, memories, keepsakes, titles and decorative papers.
steps.description: Draw or doodle on the page to give it added depth.

steps.headline: Make a last page with a quote or poem to the person's memory.
steps.description: You may want to choose prose or poetry that gives a heartfelt but hopeful wish for the person.

steps.headline: Display your photo album at family gatherings or take it out each year at their birthday.
steps.description: Scrapbooks are meant to be enjoyed and added to.
